title: Who does this
text: When you look back a week, month year.. you have to ask yourself. Why did I spend anytime on that app. Maybe to see what others are doing or to get some good advice from like minded ppl. This is because fortunate ppl have fortunate lives and even if yours isn't that back you become so full of visual stimulation you actually visualize yourself in the video, clip, feed or what ever. Well guess what you not them and that's what life is really about. Being different and facing challenges on your own terms. So, other than that I think it's pretty fun to push my limits for tolerance and misuse while other might not be that interesting even when they pay. It's just too bad but thats what happen in life until the next train ride out of town shows up.

title: New algorithm is killing this app
text:
I've read a few other reviews and many of the stories also seem to apply to me. I've been using Instagram for years and I loved how it was a relevant social media platform that's not completely bogged down by ads and politics.

I loved being able to see what my friends and family are up to in a visual medium, which used to be the entire point of Instagram. Then, they started featuring more and more ads and the more they pushed with the ads, the less I would visit the app. However, around this time they also changed the feed algorithm, no longer sorting it by the most recent post, so whenever I go on it, my entire feed is at least 10 days old. I no longer enjoy scrolling through my Instagram feed, because instead of being able to immediately interact with the photos, I need to check the date on each one first. Scrolling through the feed has become a chore and as a result, I only visit the app about once a month now. I've debated deleting my account multiple times and if they do not revert back to the old algorithm soon, I probably will because I can't justify keeping an app on my phone that I don't use it enjoy.

At the very least, I can understand some ads here and there because companies need revenue, but I implore Instagram to please listen to millions of their users and sort feeds by recency again.

title: New sensitive content filter is different for everyone
text: I‚Äôve enjoyed using Instagram for the past couple years now, and they just recently added the ‚ÄúSensitive Content Control‚Äù feature. The only problem with this is NOT EVERYONE has the ‚Äúallow all‚Äù setting, myself included. The filter is on at all times for me and I can only choose between ‚Äúlimit‚Äù and ‚Äúlimit even more‚Äù. This doesn‚Äôt sound bad on paper, but I‚Äôve been using Instagram largely to check in on the crisis in Cuba as well as other world events that are inevitably going to have some moderately disturbing videos associated with them, and since this feature was added, I have not been able to see a single post relating to any of these events. title: Privacy violations despite their ‚Äúpolicies‚Äù
text: Desperate for increased user numbers and revenue, Instagram (Meta, Facebook) has devolved into a major violator of user privacy. They are effectively selling your location data to their advertisers. Also, Instagram will access your contacts in other Apps such as LinkedIn and Outlook even if you have settings set to block them from doing so. For people like me who keep their business life very separate from their personal life and social media, this is very easy to prove. Apple should penalize Instagram/Meta for these privacy violations but so far, crickets. I‚Äôm hoping a class action lawsuit will force Meta to change their ways, but most likely they will always find a way to get around any laws or penalties. If you allow Instagram on your device you should know that none of their settings should be interpreted to mean that Instagram will abide by them.
